Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that all schools in Uganda were closed in March 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The claim suggests that girls returned to school in Uganda after the pandemic shutdown, which is not accurate.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or supporting information to prove that girls actually returned to school in Uganda after the pandemic shutdown. The only evidence provided is an image showing young women in blue uniforms, but it is later revealed that the image is not from Uganda and is instead related to expelled pregnant girls in Tanzania.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the image of young women in blue uniforms represents girls returning to school in Uganda after the pandemic shutdown. However, it is later clarified that the image is unrelated to Uganda and instead depicts expelled pregnant girls in Tanzania.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the image used in the claim is not related to girls returning to school in Uganda after the pandemic shutdown, but rather depicts expelled pregnant girls in Tanzania attending vocational training at the Faraja Center.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the situation by suggesting that girls have returned to school in Uganda after the pandemic shutdown without providing sufficient evidence or verifying the accuracy of the image used.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters in accurately representing the situation of girls returning to school in Uganda after the pandemic shutdown. It relies on an unrelated image and lacks sufficient evidence or support.
Other potential biases: It is difficult to determine other biases without additional context or information.
